questions.question_text: What is the engine model number for the Cessna 172M?
questions.correct_answer: Lycoming O-320-E2D

questions.question_text: What is the engine horsepower rating for a Cessna 172N? [1]
questions.correct_answer: 160 BHP at 2700 RPM

questions.question_text: In a Cessna 172M with standard tanks, what is the total USABLE fuel capacity? [3]
questions.correct_answer: 38 gallons

questions.question_text: What is the total USABLE fuel capacity of a Cessna 172N equipped with long-range tanks? [1]
questions.correct_answer: 50 gallons

questions.question_text: What is the maximum certificated takeoff weight for a Cessna 172M/N in the Normal Category? [4, 7]
questions.correct_answer: 2300 lbs

questions.question_text: What is the maximum certificated takeoff weight for a Cessna 172M/N in the Utility Category? [4, 7]
questions.correct_answer: 2000 lbs

questions.question_text: What is the oil sump capacity of the Lycoming O-320-E2D engine in the Cessna 172M? [7]
questions.correct_answer: 8 Quarts

questions.question_text: What is the Never Exceed Speed (Vne) for the Cessna 172M/N? [3, 25]
questions.correct_answer: 160 KIAS

questions.question_text: What is the Maximum Structural Cruising Speed (Vno) for the Cessna 172M/N? [3, 25]
questions.correct_answer: 128 KIAS

questions.question_text: What is the Maximum Flap Extended Speed (Vfe) for the Cessna 172M? [3]
questions.correct_answer: 85 KIAS

questions.question_text: What does the upper limit of the white arc on the airspeed indicator signify? [3]
questions.correct_answer: Maximum flap extended speed

questions.question_text: What does the lower limit of the white arc on the airspeed indicator signify? [3]
options: Stalling speed in the clean configuration (Vs1)
Stalling speed in the landing configuration (Vso)
questions.correct_answer: Stalling speed in the landing configuration (Vso)

questions.question_text: The green arc on the airspeed indicator represents the normal operating range. What is its upper limit? [3]
questions.correct_answer: Vno (Maximum Structural Cruising Speed)

questions.question_text: What is the maximum window open speed for the Cessna 172M/N? [3, 25]
questions.correct_answer: 160 KIAS

questions.question_text: What is the maximum baggage allowance for a Cessna 172N operating in the Normal Category? [4]
questions.correct_answer: 120 lbs

questions.question_text: When operating a Cessna 172N in the Utility Category, what is the limitation regarding baggage and rear seat occupants? [4]
options: Rear seat must be empty, baggage is allowed up to 50 lbs
Baggage compartment and rear seat must not be occupied
Only one rear seat occupant is allowed
Baggage is limited to 120 lbs, rear seat can be occupied
questions.correct_answer: Baggage compartment and rear seat must not be occupied

questions.question_text: What is the approved fuel grade for the Cessna 172N? [1]
questions.correct_answer: 100LL Grade Aviation Fuel (Blue)

questions.question_text: What is the horsepower rating of the Lycoming O-320-E2D engine in a Cessna 172M? [2]
questions.correct_answer: 150 BHP at 2700 RPM

questions.question_text: What is the maximum engine speed for the Cessna 172N? [1]
questions.correct_answer: 2700 RPM

questions.question_text: What is the normal operating range (green arc) for the oil temperature gauge in a Cessna 172N? [6]
What is the maximum allowable oil pressure in a Cessna 172N? [1]
questions.correct_answer: 100 psi

questions.question_text: What is the minimum allowable oil pressure in a Cessna 172N? [1]
questions.correct_answer: 25 psi

questions.question_text: What is the maneuvering speed (Va) for a Cessna 172M at 2300 lbs? [3]
questions.correct_answer: 97 KIAS

questions.question_text: What is the best glide speed for a Cessna 172N at gross weight with flaps up?
questions.correct_answer: 65 KIAS

questions.question_text: During a pre-flight check, where are the fuel tank sumps located for draining?
options: Under each wing, near the fuselage
Inside the cabin, under the seats
questions.correct_answer: Under each wing, near the fuselage

questions.question_text: What is the recommended action regarding the fuel selector valve position when refueling a Cessna 172 to ensure maximum capacity? [18]
options: Place the selector in either LEFT or RIGHT position
The selector position does not affect refueling
questions.correct_answer: Place the selector in either LEFT or RIGHT position

questions.question_text: What is the maximum demonstrated crosswind component for the Cessna 172? [15]
questions.correct_answer: 15 knots

questions.question_text: The electrical system in a 1978 Cessna 172N is a:
questions.correct_answer: 28-volt system

questions.question_text: What is the amperage of the alternator in a standard Cessna 172N? [20]
questions.correct_answer: 60-amp

questions.question_text: In a Cessna 172, what is the primary purpose of the fuel selector valve's 'BOTH' position? [18]
options: For takeoff, climb, landing, and maneuvers
Used to balance fuel load in cruise
questions.correct_answer: For takeoff, climb, landing, and maneuvers

questions.question_text: What is the first step in the POH checklist for an engine fire during start on the ground?
questions.correct_answer: Continue Cranking

questions.question_text: In the event of an engine failure in flight, what is the first recommended action in the POH?
questions.correct_answer: Establish best glide speed (65 KIAS)

questions.question_text: What is the recommended flap setting for a short-field takeoff?
questions.correct_answer: 10 degrees

questions.question_text: For a normal landing in a Cessna 172, what is the typical final approach speed with full flaps? [24]
questions.correct_answer: 55-65 KIAS

questions.question_text: What does a continuous discharge shown on the ammeter during flight indicate?
questions.correct_answer: Alternator malfunction

questions.question_text: What is the normal operating range for the suction gauge in a Cessna 172N? [14]
questions.correct_answer: 4.5 to 5.4 inches of mercury

questions.question_text: If you experience a vacuum system failure in IMC, which two instruments will become unreliable? [2]
options: Turn Coordinator and Vertical Speed Indicator
questions.correct_answer: Attitude Indicator and Directional Gyro

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the carburetor heat control?
options: To increase engine power during takeoff
To prevent or melt carburetor ice
To lean the fuel-air mixture at high altitudes
To cool the engine during prolonged climbs
questions.correct_answer: To prevent or melt carburetor ice

questions.question_text: When applying carburetor heat, what effect should be observed on the engine's RPM?
questions.correct_answer: A slight decrease in RPM

questions.question_text: What is the maximum RPM drop allowed during a magneto check at 1700 RPM? [24]
questions.correct_answer: 125 RPM

questions.question_text: What is the maximum allowable RPM differential between the left and right magnetos during a run-up check? [24]
questions.correct_answer: 50 RPM

questions.question_text: How is venting for the fuel system primarily accomplished in a Cessna 172M? [18]
options: A vent line from the left tank and a vented right fuel cap
A single vent tube under the fuselage
questions.correct_answer: A vent line from the left tank and a vented right fuel cap

questions.question_text: What type of propeller is standard on a Cessna 172M/N? [1, 2]
questions.correct_answer: Fixed-pitch, 2-blade

questions.question_text: What is the wing area of a Cessna 172M/N? [2, 4]
questions.correct_answer: 174 square feet

questions.question_text: In the event of an electrical fire in flight (smoke in cabin), what is the POH-recommended first action after shutting off the master switch?
options: Close all vents and cabin heat
questions.correct_answer: Close all vents and cabin heat

questions.question_text: What is the recommended entry speed for a steep turn?
questions.correct_answer: 95 KIAS

questions.question_text: What is the flap setting for a balked landing (go-around)? [32]
questions.correct_answer: Retract to 20°

questions.question_text: The stall warning horn is designed to activate at what speed range above the actual stall?
questions.correct_answer: 5-10 knots

questions.question_text: What is the definition of 'Reference Datum' in the context of weight and balance? [13]
options: The center of the main landing gear
The tip of the propeller spinner
An imaginary vertical plane from which all horizontal distances are measured
The rearmost point of the aircraft fuselage
questions.correct_answer: An imaginary vertical plane from which all horizontal distances are measured

questions.question_text: What is the maximum load factor (flaps up) for a Cessna 172N in the Normal Category? [27]
What is the maximum load factor (flaps up) for a Cessna 172N in the Utility Category? [27]
What is the maximum load factor with flaps fully extended in both Normal and Utility categories? [27]
According to the POH, what action should be taken if the oil temperature exceeds the maximum (red line) during flight?
options: Land as soon as possible to investigate
Lean the mixture to cool the engine
questions.correct_answer: Land as soon as possible to investigate

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the fuel strainer drain?
options: To check for proper fuel octane
To remove any water and sediment from the fuel system
questions.correct_answer: To remove any water and sediment from the fuel system

questions.question_text: How many fuel sumps are there to be drained during a preflight on a standard Cessna 172M/N?
options: One, at the lowest point of the fuselage
Two, one under each wing root
Three, one under each wing tank and one for the fuel strainer
Five, two under each wing and one for the fuel strainer
questions.correct_answer: Five, two under each wing and one for the fuel strainer

questions.question_text: What type of landing gear does the Cessna 172 have? [7]
questions.correct_answer: Fixed tricycle gear

questions.question_text: How are the brakes actuated on a Cessna 172? [18]
options: Electrically via a switch on the yoke
Hydraulically via master cylinders connected to the pilot's rudder pedals
Mechanically via cables connected to a hand lever
questions.correct_answer: Hydraulically via master cylinders connected to the pilot's rudder pedals

questions.question_text: What is the function of the mixture control?
options: To control the amount of air entering the carburetor
To control the fuel-to-air ratio entering the cylinders
To select which fuel tank is being used
To prime the engine before starting
questions.correct_answer: To control the fuel-to-air ratio entering the cylinders

questions.question_text: Leaning the mixture during cruise flight at altitude results in:
options: Increased fuel consumption and lower engine temperatures
Decreased fuel consumption and higher engine temperatures
Better engine cooling and increased power
Lower fuel consumption and optimal engine performance
questions.correct_answer: Lower fuel consumption and optimal engine performance

questions.question_text: What is the static RPM range for a Cessna 172N during a full-throttle run-up? [1]
What is the procedure for executing a 180° turn in clouds after an inadvertent entry, assuming a vacuum system failure? [6]
options: Make a steep, 45-degree bank turn using the turn coordinator
Make a standard rate turn using the turn coordinator for 60 seconds
Make a shallow, 10-degree bank turn using the attitude indicator
questions.correct_answer: Make a standard rate turn using the turn coordinator for 60 seconds

questions.question_text: If the alternate static source is used, what effect does this have on the airspeed indicator and altimeter readings?
options: Both will read lower than actual
Both will read higher than actual
Airspeed will read higher, altimeter will read lower
Airspeed and altimeter will be unaffected
questions.correct_answer: Both will read higher than actual

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the manual primer? [18]
options: To inject fuel directly into the fuel strainer for cleaning
To inject fuel directly into the cylinder intake ports for starting
To add oil to the fuel for lubrication
To remove air from the fuel lines
questions.correct_answer: To inject fuel directly into the cylinder intake ports for starting

questions.question_text: What is the recommended action if a landing must be made with a flat main tire?
options: Land on the side of the runway corresponding to the good tire
Land at a higher than normal speed
Land with full flaps and hold the nose wheel off as long as possible
Land with no flaps to minimize wing loading
questions.correct_answer: Land on the side of the runway corresponding to the good tire

questions.question_text: What is the recommended procedure for a soft-field takeoff?
options: Use 20 degrees of flaps and keep the nose wheel on the ground as long as possible
Use 10 degrees of flaps, hold full back pressure, and lift off at the lowest possible airspeed
Use no flaps and perform a high-speed taxi before rotation
Use full flaps and climb at Vx
questions.correct_answer: Use 10 degrees of flaps, hold full back pressure, and lift off at the lowest possible airspeed

questions.question_text: What is the recommended procedure for a soft-field landing?
options: Land at a higher speed to ensure positive control
Use minimal flaps and land flat
Use full flaps, land at the slowest possible airspeed, and keep the nose wheel off the ground as long as possible
Apply brakes immediately upon touchdown to minimize rollout
questions.correct_answer: Use full flaps, land at the slowest possible airspeed, and keep the nose wheel off the ground as long as possible

questions.question_text: What is the significance of the yellow arc on the airspeed indicator? [3]
options: Structural caution range, for smooth air only
questions.correct_answer: Structural caution range, for smooth air only

questions.question_text: What is the total fuel capacity (not usable) of a Cessna 172N with standard tanks? [1]
questions.correct_answer: 43 gallons

questions.question_text: What is the total fuel capacity (not usable) of a Cessna 172M with long-range tanks? [3]
questions.correct_answer: 52 gallons

questions.question_text: What is the first action in the 'Securing Aircraft' checklist after landing? [32]
questions.correct_answer: Set the parking brake

questions.question_text: In a Cessna 172N, if the ammeter shows a continuous charge of more than two needle widths while in flight, what is the likely problem?
options: The battery is low and charging normally
Normal operation with electrical equipment on
questions.correct_answer: An over-voltage condition

questions.question_text: What is the procedure for an emergency descent as recommended by the POH?
options: Throttle idle, mixture rich, flaps as required, and a steep bank up to 45 degrees
Throttle full, mixture full rich, flaps up, and a shallow dive
Throttle idle, mixture idle cut-off, flaps full, and a straight-ahead descent
Throttle idle, flaps up, and maintain Vne in a steep descent
questions.correct_answer: Throttle idle, mixture rich, flaps as required, and a steep bank up to 45 degrees

questions.question_text: What is the primary flight control surface for initiating a turn?
questions.correct_answer: Ailerons

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the rudder during a turn?
options: To increase the rate of turn
To counteract adverse yaw and coordinate the turn
questions.correct_answer: To counteract adverse yaw and coordinate the turn

questions.question_text: What is the maximum combined weight capacity for baggage area 1 (station 82-108) and area 2 (station 108-142) in a Cessna 172N? [4]
questions.correct_answer: 120 lbs

questions.question_text: What is the maximum weight allowed in baggage area 2 (the extended rear area) alone? [4]
questions.correct_answer: 50 lbs

questions.question_text: What is the correct procedure if an engine fire develops in flight?
options: Increase airspeed to blow out the fire, then land immediately
Shut off fuel, turn off master switch, close vents, and perform an emergency descent
Descend to a lower altitude and enrich the mixture
Turn on carburetor heat and open the cowl flaps
questions.correct_answer: Shut off fuel, turn off master switch, close vents, and perform an emergency descent

questions.question_text: How is the wing flap system operated in a Cessna 172M/N? [7]
options: Manually via a lever between the seats
Electrically via a switch on the instrument panel
Pneumatically using bleed air from the engine
questions.correct_answer: Electrically via a switch on the instrument panel

questions.question_text: What is the maximum flap setting available on a Cessna 172M?
questions.correct_answer: 40 degrees

questions.question_text: What is the maximum flap setting available on a later model Cessna 172N (1979 onwards)?
questions.correct_answer: 30 degrees

questions.question_text: What is the primary source of cabin heat in a Cessna 172?
options: A shroud around the engine exhaust muffler
Bleed air from the vacuum pump
A combustion heater in the tail cone
questions.correct_answer: A shroud around the engine exhaust muffler

questions.question_text: What is a potential hazard associated with using cabin heat?
options: Carbon monoxide poisoning if the exhaust shroud is cracked
questions.correct_answer: Carbon monoxide poisoning if the exhaust shroud is cracked

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the pitot tube?
options: To measure static air pressure for the altimeter
To measure ram air pressure for the airspeed indicator
To provide ventilation for the cabin
questions.correct_answer: To measure ram air pressure for the airspeed indicator

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the static port?
options: To provide a source of undisturbed ambient air pressure for the altimeter, VSI, and airspeed indicator
To drain moisture from the instrument lines
questions.correct_answer: To provide a source of undisturbed ambient air pressure for the altimeter, VSI, and airspeed indicator

questions.question_text: If the pitot tube becomes blocked but the static port remains clear, which instrument will be affected and how?
options: The altimeter will freeze at the altitude of the blockage
The airspeed indicator will act like an altimeter, reading higher in a climb and lower in a descent
The vertical speed indicator will show a constant climb
The airspeed indicator will drop to zero
questions.correct_answer: The airspeed indicator will act like an altimeter, reading higher in a climb and lower in a descent

questions.question_text: If the static port becomes blocked, which instruments will give inaccurate readings?
options: Airspeed indicator, attitude indicator, and directional gyro
Airspeed indicator, altimeter, and vertical speed indicator
Tachometer, oil pressure gauge, and fuel gauges
questions.correct_answer: Airspeed indicator, altimeter, and vertical speed indicator

questions.question_text: What is the recommended action if you suspect carburetor ice is forming?
options: Lean the mixture and increase power
Descend to a lower, warmer altitude
questions.correct_answer: Immediately apply full carburetor heat

questions.question_text: What is the definition of 'Arm' in weight and balance calculations? [13]
options: The weight of an object multiplied by its distance from the datum
The total weight of the aircraft
The horizontal distance from the reference datum to the center of gravity of an item
The location of the center of gravity
questions.correct_answer: The horizontal distance from the reference datum to the center of gravity of an item

questions.question_text: What is the definition of 'Moment' in weight and balance calculations? [13]
options: The total empty weight of the aircraft
The product of the weight of an item multiplied by its arm
The distance from the datum to the CG
questions.correct_answer: The product of the weight of an item multiplied by its arm

questions.question_text: An aircraft loaded with a center of gravity that is too far aft will exhibit what flight characteristics?
options: Difficulty in raising the nose for takeoff and landing
Increased longitudinal stability and slow cruise speeds
Instability, making it difficult to recover from a stall
questions.correct_answer: Instability, making it difficult to recover from a stall

questions.question_text: An aircraft loaded with a center of gravity that is too far forward will exhibit what flight characteristics?
options: Very easy to flare for landing
Difficulty in raising the nose, especially during takeoff and landing
questions.correct_answer: Difficulty in raising the nose, especially during takeoff and landing

questions.question_text: What is the effect of high density altitude on takeoff performance? [22]
options: Shorter takeoff roll and increased climb rate
Longer takeoff roll and reduced climb rate
Shorter takeoff roll and reduced climb rate
questions.correct_answer: Longer takeoff roll and reduced climb rate

questions.question_text: According to the POH, how should takeoff distance be adjusted for operation on a dry, grass runway? [30]
options: Increase distance by 15% of the 'ground roll' figure
Increase distance by 30% of the total distance over a 50-ft obstacle
questions.correct_answer: Increase distance by 15% of the 'ground roll' figure

questions.question_text: What is the procedure for recovering from a spin?
options: Power to full, ailerons neutral, full rudder opposite spin, and elevator forward
Power to idle, ailerons with the spin, rudder neutral, and elevator back
Power to idle, ailerons neutral, full rudder opposite spin, and elevator control forward to break the stall
Power to full, flaps to 20 degrees, and pull back firmly on the elevator
questions.correct_answer: Power to idle, ailerons neutral, full rudder opposite spin, and elevator control forward to break the stall

questions.question_text: Are intentional spins permitted in a Cessna 172N when operating in the Normal Category?
options: Yes, but only with flaps retracted
Only if the aircraft is below 2000 lbs
questions.correct_answer: No, spins are prohibited

questions.question_text: Intentional spins are only permitted when the aircraft is in which category?
questions.correct_answer: Utility Category

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the elevator trim?
options: To move the elevator directly for pitch control
To relieve control pressures and maintain a desired pitch attitude
To assist in banking the aircraft
questions.correct_answer: To relieve control pressures and maintain a desired pitch attitude

questions.question_text: During a preflight, you notice the stall warning opening is blocked. What is the consequence?
options: The stall warning horn will sound continuously
The airspeed indicator will be inaccurate
The stall warning system will be inoperative
questions.correct_answer: The stall warning system will be inoperative

questions.question_text: What is the source of power for the stall warning horn?
questions.correct_answer: Aircraft electrical system

questions.question_text: What is the correct response to a 'LOW VOLTAGE' annunciation in flight?
options: Turn on all electrical equipment to increase the load
Turn off the alternator, reduce electrical load, and land as soon as practical
Cycle the master switch several times
Ignore it unless the battery dies
questions.correct_answer: Turn off the alternator, reduce electrical load, and land as soon as practical

questions.question_text: What is the flap operating range (white arc) for a Cessna 172M? [3]
questions.correct_answer: 41-85 KIAS

questions.question_text: What is the normal operating range (green arc) for a Cessna 172M? [3]
questions.correct_answer: 47-128 KIAS

questions.question_text: What is the caution range (yellow arc) for a Cessna 172M/N? [3]
What is the best rate of climb speed (Vy) at sea level for a Cessna 172N?
questions.correct_answer: 73 KIAS

questions.question_text: What is the best angle of climb speed (Vx) at sea level for a Cessna 172N?
questions.correct_answer: 59 KIAS

questions.question_text: If a landing with flaps up is necessary, how should the approach speed be adjusted? [22]
options: Keep the same speed as a normal landing
questions.correct_answer: Increase by 9 KIAS

questions.question_text: What is the service ceiling of a Cessna 172N? [11]
questions.correct_answer: 14,200 feet

questions.question_text: What is the primary difference between Vs1 and Vso?
options: Vs1 is the stall speed with flaps up, Vso is with flaps down
Vs1 is the stall speed at gross weight, Vso is at minimum weight
Vs1 is the stall speed in a turn, Vso is in level flight
Vs1 is the stall speed with power on, Vso is with power off
questions.correct_answer: Vs1 is the stall speed with flaps up, Vso is with flaps down

questions.question_text: What is the power source for the magnetos?
options: They are engine-driven and self-contained, requiring no external electrical power
questions.correct_answer: They are engine-driven and self-contained, requiring no external electrical power

questions.question_text: Why is it important to check that the ignition switch is OFF during the pre-flight inspection?
options: To prevent accidental starting of the engine if the propeller is moved
To allow the GPS to acquire satellites
questions.correct_answer: To prevent accidental starting of the engine if the propeller is moved

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'Master Switch'?
options: It only controls the ignition system
It controls all the lights on the aircraft
It is a split switch that controls the main battery and the alternator
questions.correct_answer: It is a split switch that controls the main battery and the alternator

questions.question_text: What is the correct procedure for starting the engine in a standard Cessna 172?
options: Mixture full rich, throttle closed, crank engine
Mixture idle cut-off, throttle open 1/4 inch, crank engine, then advance mixture
Mixture full rich, throttle open 1/4 to 1/8 inch, prime as required, then crank engine
Mixture half, throttle full, crank engine
questions.correct_answer: Mixture full rich, throttle open 1/4 to 1/8 inch, prime as required, then crank engine

questions.question_text: What is the indication of a failed alternator?
options: A positive reading on the ammeter
A negative (discharge) reading on the ammeter and a 'LOW VOLTAGE' annunciator light
The engine RPM will decrease significantly
questions.correct_answer: A negative (discharge) reading on the ammeter and a 'LOW VOLTAGE' annunciator light

questions.question_text: How long can the battery be expected to supply power to essential equipment after an alternator failure? [21]
questions.correct_answer: Approximately 30 minutes

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the circuit breakers in the electrical system?
options: To act as on/off switches for all equipment
To protect electrical circuits from overloads
To regulate voltage from the alternator
To increase the amperage to certain components
questions.correct_answer: To protect electrical circuits from overloads

questions.question_text: If a circuit breaker pops in flight, what is the recommended procedure?
options: Reset it immediately and continue to do so if it pops again
Leave it out for the remainder of the flight
Wait a few minutes for it to cool, then reset it once. If it pops again, do not reset.
Land immediately at the nearest airport
questions.correct_answer: Wait a few minutes for it to cool, then reset it once. If it pops again, do not reset.

questions.question_text: What is the tire pressure for the main wheels on a Cessna 172? [24]
questions.correct_answer: 29 psi

questions.question_text: What is the tire pressure for the nose wheel on a Cessna 172? [24]
questions.correct_answer: 31 psi

questions.question_text: What is the primary method of steering the aircraft during taxi?
options: Using the rudder pedals to control the nosewheel, supplemented by differential braking
Using the elevator to lift the nosewheel
questions.correct_answer: Using the rudder pedals to control the nosewheel, supplemented by differential braking

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the oil breather line?
options: To add oil to the engine
To vent excess pressure from the crankcase
questions.correct_answer: To vent excess pressure from the crankcase

questions.question_text: What is the minimum turning radius of a Cessna 172M/N? [4]
What is the wingspan of a Cessna 172M/N? [23]
questions.correct_answer: 35.83 feet

questions.question_text: What is the recommended oil type for a Cessna 172N after the initial break-in period? [1]
options: MIL-L-6082 Aviation Grade Straight Mineral Oil
questions.correct_answer: MIL-L-22851 Ashless Dispersant Oil

questions.question_text: During a run-up, what is the indication that carburetor heat is working properly?
options: A slight, momentary rise in RPM followed by a decrease
A slight, immediate decrease in RPM
A significant, sustained increase in RPM
No change in engine parameters, but the 'CARB HEAT' light illuminates
questions.correct_answer: A slight, immediate decrease in RPM

questions.question_text: What is the procedure for a power-off stall recovery?
options: Simultaneously decrease pitch attitude, apply full power, and level the wings
Apply full power first, then lower the nose
Lower the nose, then apply power once airspeed increases
Level the wings, then apply power and lower the nose
questions.correct_answer: Simultaneously decrease pitch attitude, apply full power, and level the wings

questions.question_text: What is the primary danger of a skid during a turn?
options: The possibility of entering a skidding stall, which can lead to a spin
Excessive load factor on the wings
questions.correct_answer: The possibility of entering a skidding stall, which can lead to a spin

questions.question_text: What is the primary danger of a slip during a turn?
options: A rapid loss of altitude and potential for a spin
A decrease in turn rate and an increase in turn radius
Excessive side-loading on the landing gear
Engine stoppage due to fuel unporting
questions.correct_answer: A decrease in turn rate and an increase in turn radius

questions.question_text: When should the fuel selector valve be operated from a single tank (LEFT or RIGHT) instead of BOTH? [18]
options: During cruising flight to balance fuel levels
It should never be moved from the BOTH position
questions.correct_answer: During cruising flight to balance fuel levels

questions.question_text: What is the consequence of taking off with the fuel selector on a nearly empty tank?
options: The engine will run rough but continue to operate
The engine will fail shortly after takeoff
The fuel will automatically draw from the fuller tank
The fuel gauges will become inaccurate
questions.correct_answer: The engine will fail shortly after takeoff

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'squat switch' on some retractable gear aircraft (though not standard on a 172)?
options: To prevent the landing gear from retracting while on the ground
To activate the stall warning horn
To turn on the landing light automatically
questions.correct_answer: To prevent the landing gear from retracting while on the ground

questions.question_text: What is the recommended action if the door opens in flight?
options: Perform an emergency descent and land
Slow the aircraft, trim for hands-off flight, and then close the door using a firm, smooth motion
Ignore it, as it poses no significant aerodynamic hazard
questions.correct_answer: Slow the aircraft, trim for hands-off flight, and then close the door using a firm, smooth motion

questions.question_text: What is the effect of extending flaps on the stalling speed?
options: It has no effect on the stalling speed
It only affects the stalling speed at high altitudes
questions.correct_answer: It decreases the stalling speed

questions.question_text: What is the effect of an increase in weight on stalling speed?
options: It only increases the stalling speed in a turn
questions.correct_answer: It increases the stalling speed

questions.question_text: What is the effect of an increased load factor (e.g., in a steep turn) on stalling speed?
options: It has no effect on the stalling speed
It only affects the stalling speed with flaps down
questions.correct_answer: It increases the stalling speed

questions.question_text: What is the primary instrument for maintaining pitch attitude during instrument flight?
questions.correct_answer: Attitude Indicator

questions.question_text: What is the primary instrument for maintaining bank during instrument flight?
questions.correct_answer: Attitude Indicator

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'Alternate Static Source' valve?
options: To provide an alternate source of electricity
To provide an alternate source of vacuum
To provide static pressure from inside the cabin if the external port is blocked
To provide an alternate source of fuel
questions.correct_answer: To provide static pressure from inside the cabin if the external port is blocked

questions.question_text: When using the alternate static source, what is the recommended action regarding cabin vents and windows?
options: Close them to ensure the most stable pressure reading
Only open the pilot's side window
questions.correct_answer: Close them to ensure the most stable pressure reading

questions.question_text: What is the maximum flap extended speed (Vfe) for flaps beyond 10 degrees in a Cessna 172N?
questions.correct_answer: 85 KIAS

questions.question_text: What is the maximum speed for extending the first 10 degrees of flaps in a 1979 Cessna 172N?
questions.correct_answer: 110 KIAS

questions.question_text: What is the primary cause of 'adverse yaw'?
options: The rudder being deflected too much
The increased drag on the outside wing in a turn
The differential drag produced by the ailerons when initiating a bank
The torque effect of the propeller
questions.correct_answer: The differential drag produced by the ailerons when initiating a bank

questions.question_text: What is 'P-factor'?
options: The tendency for the aircraft to roll left due to propeller torque
The gyroscopic precession effect of the propeller
The asymmetric thrust from the propeller at high angles of attack, causing a yawing moment to the left
The spiraling slipstream hitting the tail
questions.correct_answer: The asymmetric thrust from the propeller at high angles of attack, causing a yawing moment to the left

questions.question_text: P-factor is most pronounced under which conditions?
options: High airspeed, low power, low angle of attack
Low airspeed, high power, high angle of attack
High airspeed, high power, low angle of attack
Low airspeed, low power, low angle of attack
questions.correct_answer: Low airspeed, high power, high angle of attack

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'bus bar' in the electrical system?
options: To act as a central distribution point for electrical power
To convert AC to DC power
questions.correct_answer: To act as a central distribution point for electrical power

questions.question_text: What is the difference between 'true airspeed' (TAS) and 'indicated airspeed' (IAS)?
options: TAS is IAS corrected for instrument error only
TAS is IAS corrected for non-standard pressure and temperature (density altitude)
TAS is always lower than IAS
questions.correct_answer: TAS is IAS corrected for non-standard pressure and temperature (density altitude)

questions.question_text: As altitude increases, what is the relationship between TAS and IAS (assuming constant power)?
options: TAS will be lower than IAS
TAS will be higher than IAS
questions.correct_answer: TAS will be higher than IAS

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'dihedral' angle of the wings?
questions.correct_answer: To improve lateral (roll) stability

questions.question_text: What is the procedure for a short-field landing?
options: A steep approach with full flaps, touching down at the minimum possible airspeed on a precise point, and applying maximum braking
A long, shallow approach with no flaps to bleed off speed
A normal approach but with heavy braking after touchdown
A high-speed approach to ensure positive control over the threshold
questions.correct_answer: A steep approach with full flaps, touching down at the minimum possible airspeed on a precise point, and applying maximum braking

questions.question_text: What is the primary risk of landing with excessive airspeed?
options: Stalling the aircraft before the runway
Floating down the runway and potentially overshooting it
A hard landing that could damage the gear
questions.correct_answer: Floating down the runway and potentially overshooting it

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'Hobbs meter'?
options: To record the total time the engine has been running
To count the number of landings
questions.correct_answer: To record the total time the engine has been running

questions.question_text: If you are performing a short-field takeoff over a 50-foot obstacle, which speed should be maintained until the obstacle is cleared?
questions.correct_answer: Vx (Best angle of climb)

questions.question_text: After clearing an obstacle on a short-field takeoff, what is the correct procedure regarding airspeed?
options: Maintain Vx until reaching cruise altitude
Immediately retract flaps and accelerate to cruise speed
Lower the nose to accelerate to Vy for a more efficient climb
Reduce power to 75% and maintain Vx
questions.correct_answer: Lower the nose to accelerate to Vy for a more efficient climb

questions.question_text: You are in cruise flight at 5,500 feet and notice the engine running rough. Applying carburetor heat causes the engine to run even rougher initially, then smooth out with an increase in RPM. What does this indicate?
options: Carburetor ice was present and has been melted
questions.correct_answer: Carburetor ice was present and has been melted

questions.question_text: During a flight in a Cessna 172N, the suction gauge drops to zero. What is the most appropriate immediate action if you are in VMC?
options: Declare an emergency and land immediately
Plan to terminate the flight as soon as practical, anticipating the loss of the attitude and heading indicators
questions.correct_answer: Plan to terminate the flight as soon as practical, anticipating the loss of the attitude and heading indicators

questions.question_text: Why is it recommended to avoid prolonged slips with low fuel in one tank?
options: It can cause the engine to overheat
It can lead to fuel unporting, where the fuel outlet is no longer submerged in fuel, causing engine failure
It can damage the fuel tank bladder
It places excessive stress on the wing structure
questions.correct_answer: It can lead to fuel unporting, where the fuel outlet is no longer submerged in fuel, causing engine failure

questions.question_text: You are on final approach for landing and your electrical system fails completely (master switch is unresponsive). What is the status of your wing flaps?
options: They will remain in their last set position and cannot be moved
They can be operated manually with a hand crank
They will slowly extend to the full down position
questions.correct_answer: They will remain in their last set position and cannot be moved

questions.question_text: If you must perform a no-flap landing due to an electrical failure, what changes to your landing technique are required?
options: Use a slower approach speed and a shorter runway
Use a faster approach speed and expect a longer landing roll
The landing technique is identical to a normal landing
Use a steeper approach angle to compensate for the lack of drag
questions.correct_answer: Use a faster approach speed and expect a longer landing roll

questions.question_text: What is the primary reason for the RPM drop when checking magnetos during a run-up?
options: The engine is running on only one magneto and a single set of spark plugs, resulting in less efficient combustion
It indicates a malfunction in the checked magneto
The engine is being deliberately overloaded to test its performance
The carburetor heat is activating simultaneously
questions.correct_answer: The engine is running on only one magneto and a single set of spark plugs, resulting in less efficient combustion

questions.question_text: If there is no RPM drop when switching to a single magneto, what is the most likely cause?
options: The engine is running exceptionally well
The ground wire for the unchecked magneto is broken or disconnected, meaning it was never actually turned off
questions.correct_answer: The ground wire for the unchecked magneto is broken or disconnected, meaning it was never actually turned off

questions.question_text: Why is it critical to check 'flight controls free and correct' during the pre-flight and before takeoff?
options: To ensure the trim is set correctly
To check the hydraulic fluid level
To ensure no control locks are installed and that the controls move in the proper direction
To warm up the control cables
questions.correct_answer: To ensure no control locks are installed and that the controls move in the proper direction

questions.question_text: You are flying at cruise power and notice the oil pressure has dropped to the bottom of the green arc (25 psi). What is the appropriate course of action?
options: Continue to your destination while monitoring the gauge
Increase power to try and raise the pressure
Assume the gauge is faulty and ignore it
Reduce power, look for a suitable place to land, and prepare for a potential engine failure
questions.correct_answer: Reduce power, look for a suitable place to land, and prepare for a potential engine failure

questions.question_text: What is the significance of the propeller's diameter specifications (e.g., Max 75 inches, Min 74 inches)? [1]
options: It indicates the range of adjustable pitch
It defines the limits for repairs; if a blade is damaged and must be filed down, it cannot be shorter than the minimum
It is the required diameter for different altitudes
It is the difference between the M and N model propellers
questions.correct_answer: It defines the limits for repairs; if a blade is damaged and must be filed down, it cannot be shorter than the minimum

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of having two separate magnetos and two spark plugs per cylinder?
options: To provide redundancy and improved combustion efficiency
To allow the engine to run on lower octane fuel
To reduce the engine's operating temperature
questions.correct_answer: To provide redundancy and improved combustion efficiency

questions.question_text: If you are taking off from a high-altitude airport on a hot day, what is the correct procedure for leaning the mixture? [22]
options: Lean for maximum RPM during the static run-up
Lean only after reaching 3,000 feet AGL
Use full rich mixture for all takeoffs regardless of altitude
Lean until the engine begins to run rough, then enrich slightly
questions.correct_answer: Lean for maximum RPM during the static run-up

questions.question_text: What is the primary aerodynamic effect of ground effect?
options: A significant increase in induced drag, requiring more power for takeoff
A reduction in induced drag, causing the aircraft to float during landing or become airborne before reaching a safe flying speed
questions.correct_answer: A reduction in induced drag, causing the aircraft to float during landing or become airborne before reaching a safe flying speed

questions.question_text: You are on a long final approach and notice you are low. What is the correct way to adjust your glide path?
options: Lower the nose to gain speed, then pull back
Add power to decrease the rate of descent, and adjust pitch to maintain airspeed
Raise the nose to stretch the glide
questions.correct_answer: Add power to decrease the rate of descent, and adjust pitch to maintain airspeed

questions.question_text: What is the relationship between maneuvering speed (Va) and aircraft weight?
options: Va is not affected by weight
Va is always a fixed value regardless of weight
questions.correct_answer: Va decreases as weight decreases

questions.question_text: Why must abrupt control movements be avoided above maneuvering speed (Va)?
options: The engine cannot handle the rapid changes in airflow
The flight controls may become ineffective
The aircraft could exceed its structural load limits
questions.correct_answer: The aircraft could exceed its structural load limits

questions.question_text: If the engine begins to run rough in heavy rain, what is a likely cause and remedy?
options: Spark plug fouling; lean the mixture
Water in the fuel; switch tanks
Excessive cooling; reduce airspeed and power
questions.correct_answer: Carburetor icing; apply carburetor heat

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'moment' value being divided by 1000 in the Cessna POH weight and balance calculations? [13]
options: To convert the value to metric units
To simplify calculations by reducing the number of digits
To account for the weight of the fuel
It is a required FAA calculation standard
questions.correct_answer: To simplify calculations by reducing the number of digits

questions.question_text: What is the primary force that opposes thrust?
questions.correct_answer: Drag

questions.question_text: What is the primary force that opposes lift?
questions.correct_answer: Weight

questions.question_text: In straight-and-level, unaccelerated flight, what is the relationship between the four forces of flight?
options: Thrust is greater than drag, and lift is greater than weight
Thrust equals drag, and lift equals weight
Thrust is less than drag, and lift is less than weight
Thrust equals lift, and drag equals weight
questions.correct_answer: Thrust equals drag, and lift equals weight

questions.question_text: What is the definition of 'density altitude'?
options: The altitude shown on the altimeter
The pressure altitude corrected for non-standard temperature
The actual height of the aircraft above ground level
The height of the aircraft above sea level
questions.correct_answer: The pressure altitude corrected for non-standard temperature

questions.question_text: What is the primary reason for using flaps during takeoff and landing?
options: To increase the aircraft's maximum speed
To increase the wing's lift and drag, allowing for steeper approaches and shorter takeoff/landing distances
To improve roll control at low speeds
To reduce the structural load on the wings
questions.correct_answer: To increase the wing's lift and drag, allowing for steeper approaches and shorter takeoff/landing distances

questions.question_text: What is the 'standard temperature' at sea level according to ISA (International Standard Atmosphere)? [2]
What is the standard temperature lapse rate with altitude in the ISA?
questions.correct_answer: Decreases 2°C per 1000 feet

questions.question_text: What is 'pressure altitude'? [2]
options: The altitude read from the altimeter when the barometric scale is set to the current local setting
The altitude read from the altimeter when the barometric scale is set to 29.92 inches of mercury
The true height above sea level
questions.correct_answer: The altitude read from the altimeter when the barometric scale is set to 29.92 inches of mercury

questions.question_text: You are cleared for takeoff and notice a large bird strike the propeller during the takeoff roll. What is the most prudent action?
options: Continue the takeoff as the propeller is robust
Abort the takeoff immediately if there is sufficient runway remaining
Continue the takeoff and plan to return for an inspection
Reduce power slightly and continue the takeoff
questions.correct_answer: Abort the takeoff immediately if there is sufficient runway remaining

questions.question_text: What is the primary instrument to use for pitch control when recovering from an unusual attitude (e.g., extreme nose high)?
questions.correct_answer: Attitude Indicator

questions.question_text: What is the correct procedure to follow if you become lost in flight (disoriented)?
options: Descend to read town names on water towers
Fly a triangular pattern to signal an emergency
Turn off all radios to save battery and focus on flying
questions.correct_answer: Climb, Conserve, Confess (the 3 C's)

questions.question_text: What is the significance of a steady red light from a control tower to an aircraft in flight?
options: Give way to other aircraft and continue circling
questions.correct_answer: Give way to other aircraft and continue circling

questions.question_text: What is the significance of a flashing green light from a control tower to an aircraft on the ground?
options: Return to starting point on airport
questions.correct_answer: Cleared to taxi

questions.question_text: What is the primary purpose of the 'detent' in the flap switch system of a Cessna 172N?
options: To mark the 10, 20, and 30 degree flap settings
To allow for manual flap operation
To increase the speed of flap extension
questions.correct_answer: To mark the 10, 20, and 30 degree flap settings

questions.question_text: What is the unusable fuel quantity in a standard Cessna 172N tank?
questions.correct_answer: 3 gallons total

questions.question_text: What is the unusable fuel quantity in a long-range Cessna 172N tank?
questions.correct_answer: 4 gallons total

questions.question_text: What is the primary difference in the engine of a Cessna 172M versus a 172N?
options: The 172M has a lower horsepower rating (150 hp vs 160 hp)
questions.correct_answer: The 172M has a lower horsepower rating (150 hp vs 160 hp)

questions.question_text: What is the primary difference in the electrical system of a pre-1978 Cessna 172 versus a 1978 172N?
options: The older models had no electrical system
The older models had a 14-volt system, while the 172N has a 28-volt system
The older models had a generator, while the 172N has an alternator
The older models had a 28-volt system, while the 172N has a 14-volt system
questions.correct_answer: The older models had a 14-volt system, while the 172N has a 28-volt system

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'ground' wire on a magneto's ignition switch?
options: To provide power to the magneto
To disable or 'kill' the magneto by grounding the primary circuit
questions.correct_answer: To disable or 'kill' the magneto by grounding the primary circuit

questions.question_text: If you are flying into an airport without an operating control tower, what is the standard procedure for announcing your position and intentions?
options: Broadcast on the emergency frequency 121.5 MHz
Broadcast on the designated Common Traffic Advisory Frequency (CTAF)
Contact the nearest ARTCC for instructions
questions.correct_answer: Broadcast on the designated Common Traffic Advisory Frequency (CTAF)

questions.question_text: What is the standard entry procedure for a traffic pattern at a non-towered airport?
options: A straight-in approach to the landing runway
A 45-degree entry to the downwind leg at pattern altitude
A direct entry to the base leg
Crossing over the field 500 feet above pattern altitude and entering on the crosswind leg
questions.correct_answer: A 45-degree entry to the downwind leg at pattern altitude

questions.question_text: What is the standard traffic pattern altitude (TPA) for a piston-engine aircraft?
questions.correct_answer: 1,000 feet AGL

questions.question_text: What is the primary risk associated with 'wake turbulence'?
options: Engine failure due to disturbed air
Loss of control due to powerful wingtip vortices, especially when following a large, heavy aircraft
questions.correct_answer: Loss of control due to powerful wingtip vortices, especially when following a large, heavy aircraft

questions.question_text: To avoid wake turbulence from a large aircraft that has just taken off, what is the recommended procedure?
options: Rotate at the same point as the large aircraft and climb above its flight path
Rotate prior to the large aircraft's rotation point and climb above its flight path
Rotate after the large aircraft's rotation point and remain below its flight path
Wait at least 10 minutes before taking off
questions.correct_answer: Rotate prior to the large aircraft's rotation point and climb above its flight path

questions.question_text: To avoid wake turbulence from a large aircraft that has just landed, what is the recommended procedure?
options: Land prior to the large aircraft's touchdown point
Land beyond the large aircraft's touchdown point
Land in the same spot as the large aircraft
questions.correct_answer: Land beyond the large aircraft's touchdown point

questions.question_text: What does the term 'KIAS' stand for? [13]
questions.correct_answer: Knots Indicated Air Speed

questions.question_text: What does the term 'BHP' stand for in relation to engine power? [9]
questions.correct_answer: Brake Horsepower

questions.question_text: What is the primary flight control that creates and controls the 'angle of attack'?
questions.correct_answer: Elevator

questions.question_text: A stall is caused by:
options: The wing exceeding its critical angle of attack
questions.correct_answer: The wing exceeding its critical angle of attack

questions.question_text: If you are on a west heading (270°) and initiate a turn to the north (360°), what initial error will the magnetic compass show?
options: It will initially indicate a turn to the south (acceleration/deceleration error)
It will lag behind the actual heading (northerly turning error)
It will lead the turn, indicating a heading past north (southerly turning error)
questions.correct_answer: It will lag behind the actual heading (northerly turning error)
